source: Banking Law
text: A Garnishee Order is an order issued by a court to attach funds belonging to a judgment debtor that are held with a bank or a third party. It prevents the bank from releasing money from the debtor’s account until the court gives further instruction. The purpose of the Garnishee Order is to ensure that the creditor can recover the amount owed by legally freezing the debtor’s funds.

source: Banking Law
text: Under a Garnishee Order, the bank is required to disclose whether the customer (the debtor) has sufficient funds and must hold those funds without allowing withdrawals. If funds are available, the court may direct the bank to transfer the required amount to the creditor. Failure of the bank to comply may lead to legal liability. This order applies only to the balance available at the time of service.

source: Banking Law
text: The Garnishee Order grants the creditor the right to access the debtor's funds held by a bank through court intervention. It restricts the debtor from withdrawing money and requires the bank to hold or pay the specified amount to the creditor once ordered. This ensures legal recovery of dues even if the debtor attempts to avoid payment.
